Package space.sunqian.fs.io

Interface CharProcessor

public interface CharProcessor
This interface represents a processor to process char data, from the specified data source, through zero or more intermediate operations, finally produces a result or side effect, and the result will be written into a destination (if any). The following example shows a typical processing: 

 CharProcessor.from(input)
     .readBlockSize(1024)
     .readLimit(1024 * 8)
     .transformer(transformer)
     .processTo(output);

There are types of methods in this interface:

  • Setting methods: set the processing arguments to the current processor before a terminal method is invoked;
  • Terminal methods: produce the processing result or side effect. Once a terminal method is invoked, the current processor will be invalid, any further operations of the current processor will be undefined;
The processor is lazy, operations on the source data are only performed when a terminal method is invoked, and the source data are consumed only as needed. Positions of the source and destination will increment by the actual read and write number.

    • readLimit

      @Nonnull @Nonnull CharProcessor readLimit(long readLimit) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Sets the maximum number of chars to read from the data source.

      This is an optional setting method.

      Parameters:
      readLimit - the maximum number of chars to read from the data source, must >= 0
      Returns:
      this
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the limit is negative

    • readBlockSize

      @Nonnull @Nonnull CharProcessor readBlockSize(int readBlockSize) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Sets the number of chars for each read operation from the data source. The default is IOKit.bufferSize(). This setting is typically used for block-based processing.

      This is an optional setting method.

      Parameters:
      readBlockSize - the number of chars for each read operation from the data source, must > 0
      Returns:
      this
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the block size is non-positive

    • transformer

      @Nonnull @Nonnull CharProcessor transformer(@Nonnull @Nonnull CharTransformer transformer)
      Adds the given transformer to this processor as the last transformer.

      When the processing starts and there is at least one transformer, the processor reads a block of data from the data source, then passes the data block to the first transformer, then passes the result of the first transformer to the next transformer, and so on. If any transformer returns null, the current transformation chain will break. The last result of the last transformer, which serves as the final result, will be written to the destination if the final result is not empty. The processor continues this read-transform loop, until it reaches the end of the data source, or read number reaches the limit value set by readLimit(long). The logic is as follows: 

      
 while (true) {
     CharSegment block = readNextBlock(blockSize, readLimit);
     CharBuffer data = block.data();
     boolean end = block.end();
     for (CharTransformer transformer : transformers) {
         if (data == null) {
             break;
         }
         data = transformer.transform(data, end);
     }
     if (notEmpty(data)) {
         writeTo(data);
     }
     if (end) {
         break;
     }
 }

      The block size is typically determined by readBlockSize(int). And the data blocks are typically read by CharReader.read(int), thus, their content may be shared with the data source. Changes to the data blocks may be reflected in the data source.

      Normally, for the data block passed to the transformer, the unconsumed portion is ignored by the processor and will not be prepended to the next passed block. Use CharTransformer.withBuffered(CharTransformer) if it is needed.

      This is an optional setting method. CharProcessor also provides some specific transformer wrappers such as: CharTransformer.withFixedSize(CharTransformer, int) and CharTransformer.withMultipleSize(CharTransformer, int).

      Parameters:
      transformer - the given transformer
      Returns:
      this

    • process

      default long process() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing and returns the actual number of chars read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method, and it is typically used to produce side effects. This method is equivalent to: 

      
 return processeTo(IOKit.nullWriter());
      Returns:
      the actual number of chars read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • processTo

      long processTo(@Nonnull @Nonnull Appendable dst) throws IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing, writes the processing result to the specified destination, and returns the actual number of chars read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The positions of the data source and destination, if any, will be incremented by the actual read and write numbers.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      dst - the specified destination
      Returns:
      the actual number of chars read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • processTo

      long processTo(char @Nonnull [] dst, int off) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException, IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing, writes the processing result to the specified destination (starting at the specified offset), and returns the actual number of chars read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The positions of the data source and destination, if any, will be incremented by the actual read and write numbers.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      dst - the specified destination
      off - the specified offset
      Returns:
      the actual number of chars read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the bounds arguments are out of bounds
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • toCharArray

      default char @Nonnull [] toCharArray() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts the processing, and returns the result as a new array. This method is equivalent to: 
      
     CharsBuilder builder = new CharsBuilder();
     processeTo(builder);
     return builder.toCharArray();

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      the processing result as a new array
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs
      See Also:
      • processTo(Appendable)

    • toString

      @Nonnull @Nonnull String toString() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts the processing, and returns the result as a new string. This method is equivalent to: 
      
     return new String(toCharArray());

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method.

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      the processing result as a new string
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs
      See Also:
      • toCharArray()

    • asReader

      @Nonnull @Nonnull Reader asReader()
      Returns this ByteProcessor as a Reader. The status and data source of this processor are shared with the returned Reader, and the returned Reader's content represents the processing result.

      The result's support is as follows:

      • mark/reset: Unsupported if any transformer(s) exist, otherwise based on the data source;
      • close: closes the data source;
      • thread safety: no;

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      this ByteProcessor as a Reader

    • asCharReader

      @Nonnull @Nonnull CharReader asCharReader()
      Returns this CharProcessor as a CharReader. The status and data source of this processor are shared with the returned CharReader, and the returned CharReader's content represents the processing result.

      The result's support is as follows:

      • mark/reset: Unsupported if any transformer(s) exist, otherwise based on the data source;
      • close: closes the data source;
      • thread safety: no;

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      this CharProcessor as a CharReader

    • toByteEncoder

      @Nonnull default @Nonnull ByteProcessor toByteEncoder(@Nonnull @Nonnull Charset charset)
      Converts this CharProcessor to a ByteProcessor with the specified charset.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      charset - the specified charset
      Returns:
      a new ByteProcessor converted from this CharProcessor with the specified charset
